div.p: I. IV:30. Tuesday

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Miss Susan Quincy was here yesterday, and took the Manuscript Volume which had belonged to Josiah Flint of Dorchester and his son Henry Flint, for half a century a Tutor at Harvard College, and which she had sent me— I answered an invitation of a Committee of the Citizens of Springfield, to a public dinner to be given there on the 3d. of this month upon the occasion of the opening of the railroad from Boston to that place, through Worcester; and the project of which imports a continuance of it to the Hudson river— I declined this invitation. But that which now absorbs great part of my time, and all my good feelings is the case of 53 African Negroes taken, at sea, off Montauk point, by Lieutt. Gedney in a Vessel of the United States employed upon the survey of the Coast; and brought into the Port of New-London— These Negroes were a fresh importation of Slaves from Africa into the Havana, against the Laws of Spain; and her Treaties with Great-Britain—purchased there under the nose of the joint Commission of Britain and Spain sitting there for the suppression of the Slave-trade— Shipped from the Havana, for another port on the Island, by two Spanish Subjects, Ruiz and Montes, the purchasers of the Slaves— When four days out, the Negroes revolted; killed the Captain and Cook of the ship; took possession of the ship; spared the lives of Ruiz and Montes, and ordered the latter, skilful in Navigation of, which they were ignorant, to steer for Sierra Leone. He deceived them by changing the course of the ship every night from that which they understood enough of navigation to make it necessary for him to steer by day— By this double process, they had as it were finally drifted upon our coast and being finally boarded by Lieutt. Gedney, he at the request of the two white men took possession of the vessel, without resistance from the negroes, and brought her into New London. 49 of the Negroes were claimed by Ruiz as his property. 4 Children—3 girls and a boy, by Montes as his property— But they charged the Negro men, with murder and Piracy, for killing the Captain and cook and taking the ship; and yet claimed all the Negroes as their property; and Lieutenant Gedney libelled the ship and Cargo, including the Negroes for Salvage— The Spanish Minister too, at Washington, has laid claim to the whole ship, Cargo and Negroes, to be restored to the owners, by virtue of the 9th. Article of the Treaty with Spain of 27. October 1795—the District judge Judson received the charge of Piracy, and committed the 49 negro men to be tried at the Circuit Court at Hartford on the 17th. of September, and the four children to appear as witnesses—and at the same time he admitted the claim of the Spaniards to the Negroes as their property, and the Libel of Captain Gedney When the Circuit Court met, on the 17th. Judge Thomson, upon a statement of the facts by the grand-jury charged them that the Court had no jurisdiction of any crime committed on the high seas, in a Spanish vessel—but he refused to liberate the Negroes upon Habeas Corpus; because they were claimed by the Spaniards as property, and he held that the District Court had jurisdiction upon this claim— More upon this subject to-morrow— I went up to Charles’s house at Sunset, and found Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks there to take tea— Charles and his wife and E. Price Greenleaf spent the Evening here.
2. IV:30 Wednesday

Deacon Spear called and paid me ten dollars for Noah Curtis for rent of the Goose Pasture till . . . the first of last April— I spoke to him about the printing of Mr Lunt’s two centennial Sermons preached last Sunday, and requested him to see and converse with Mr Thomas Greenleaf, as to the best manner of asking a copy of them for publication, with a view to secure the profit of it to Mr Lunt— Charles and his wife and children and Elizabeth C Adams dined with us— Abby and Mary and Elizabeth went round among the Ladies of the Parish, to set on foot a subscription, for making a present to Mr Lunt— I called at his house this afternoon, and cordially congratulated him on his success. Charles was here part of the Evening— Mary and Miss Cutts, with Charles’s wife spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— I finished reading the third Volume of Grahame’s History of the United States, with which I have been as well pleased as I had been with the two preceding volumes which I read soon after their first publication— This is the first European writer who has dealt out any manner of Justice to the New England Colonies— With an extraordinary exertion and in too much haste I answered the Letter of Ellis Gray Loring; of 23d. Septr—but upon the facts stated I thought best to answer by questioning him in turn— I examined Blackstone 4.71—Bacon’s Abridgement 5.310.11. Valin Book 3. Title 9. Article 3. Emerigon—Chap 12 Section 28—U.S. Laws. 1.268. Article 9. of Treaty of 28. Octr. 1795 with Spain and Vol: 3. p. 529. punishment of Piracy— Wheeler’s Law of Slavery p. 267—from 3. Sergeant and Rawles Reports 4. Peters condensed reports 4.392 Palmers case. 6 30. case of the Antelope and Masons Reports. p. 360 case of the Sloop. Abby, and all the published accounts of the proceedings in the Circuit and District Courts in the case of the Amistad. Here is an enormous consumption of time, only to perplex myself with a multitude of questions; upon which I cannot yet make up opinions for which I am willing to be responsible Emancipator 5. Septr. 1839—first account of the capture of the Amistad— Letter of Lieutt. Gedney. U.S. brig Washington. New-London 26. Augt. 1839—gives the account of his taking the Amistad that day, lying in shore off Culloden point between Gardners and Montauk points—20 or 30 negroes on the beach—54 blacks and two passengers on board—Pedro Montes and Jose Ruiz— They had been boarded by an American Schooner from Kingston— The vessel was at Anchor off Culloden point and were found in communication with the shore— The negroes on shore were disarmed, and sent on board the Schooner by Lieutt. Gedney— Qu: what authority had Lieutt. Gedney to disarm and send them on board the Schooner?— Examination before Andrew T. Judson, District judge, who committed them for trial before the U.S. Circuit Court on the 17th. of September at Hartford.— Affidavit of Jose Ruiz. reported for and in the Sun— Advertisement of Simeon L. Jocelyn, Joshua Leavitt and Lewis Tappan—4. Septr. 1839.—appeal to the friends of humanity for donations for 38 fellow-men— Emancipator of 12. Septr. 1839. Letter from Lewis Tappan, to the Committee on behalf of the African Prisoners at New-Haven—dated New-Haven 9. Septr. and one from Joshua Leavitt of 6. Septr— With Lewis Tappan’s Letter are two Warrants of Commitment—by judge Judson of 58 negroes, for the murder of Ramon Ferrer on the High Seas, and of the four children as witnesses—29. Augt. 1839—
3. IV:30. Thursday

I received last Evening an invitation from the Massachusetts charitable mechanic association to attend at their triennial festival this day to conclude with a public dinner at Faneuil Hall— I went with Thomas in Charles’s Chaise, and at 10 O’Clock attended at the Doric Hall of the State House, and met the President of the Society, Mr George Darracott, and the Secretary J. Gorham Rogers— There among the invited guests I met Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn, Caleb Cushing, Isaac P. Davis, President Josiah Quincy, the British Consul Mr Grattan, and sundry others. At 11. O’Clock, or soon after the processions moved from the Representative Hall of the State House to the Odeon— I walked with Genl. Dearborn— The order of services was 1 Voluntary on the organ 2. Chorus—Glory be to God on high. 3. Prayer by Revd. George Blagden: 4. Original Ode, written by George Lunt—a luxuriant picture of the autumnal Season, of which the following couplets are worthy of being embalmed in Memory

lg.l: The teeming earth with treasur’d stores in rich profusion crown’d
The cattle on a thousand hills, by Summer’s Sun embrown’d
The Forest deck’d with glorious hues, the flocks that throng the vale
And Nature’s universal heart, the year of plenty hail—
And well may Man whose living soul the breath of God inspires
To grasp the shadowy things to be, with uncontroll’d desires.
Well may he bring the skilful works, his master hand hath wrought,
And join with Nature’s festival, the harvest-home of thought.
His said hath found the farthest isle, that crowns the ocean wave
His hand hath sought the sparkling gem in earth’s profoundest cave
His car along the smoking track, the courser’s speed outvies
And swifter than on Eagles wings, along the deep he flies—

div.p: There are three Stanzas more, not equal to these but yet very good— Next was the Address by James T. Austin; an hour and a half long, without a tedious moment to the Auditory.— It was a spirited and eloquent vindication of the natural and unavoidable inequalities of human Society, and of the blessings of luxury. The Doctrine of Mandeville’s Fable of the Bees set forth in the gorgeous attire of ambitious Oratory. After the Doxology to the tune of old hundred, and the benediction by Mr Blagden, the procession marched again: passing through Quincy Hall over the Aerial bridge into Faneuil Hall where about nine hundred persons sat down to a most sumptuous dinner followed by toasts and songs, and shouts of exultation and of laughter, all with the most perfect sobriety decorum and order— The second toast given by the President Mr Darracott was my name with the appendage of a fulsome and disgusting compliment— It was received with loud and universal shouting and huzzas so mortifying that they totally disconcerted me.— But I was doomed to make a Speech; and muttered a few incoherent stammering sentences, without either a joke or a point to keep up the good humour— The shout and clapping that followed it was a substitute of civility for applause: President Quincy, and the Mayor of the City responded better, and the Orator of the day, and Caleb Cushing better still— I left the table about 7. O’Clock with President Quincy, and our departure from the Hall was honoured with the farewell of three hearty Cheers— I got home about 8. and joined our Ladies who were at Charles’s— We came home however before nine, my wife being slightly indisposed.
4. IV:15 Friday

Mr Dijah Bowen, who was here early in the Summer came again this day with a claim for 320 Acres of land as Assignee or Attorney for Pierre Gedeon a coloured man who in the year 1815. enlisted in the Legion of the Franks under Brigadier General Humbert. Mr Bowen left with me 1. A certificate signed by Genl. Humbert dated 8. April 1815. New-Orleans that Gedeon had enlisted in the Legion of the Franks, to serve during the War had faithfully performed his duty as a soldier, and was entitled to receive a bounty of 320 Acres of Land from Government agreeably to the act of Congress of 10. Decr. 1814.— A discharge of Pierre Gédéon of the same 8 April 1815 signed by Genl. Humbert—endorsed 26 April 1815 as registered by J. Brent jr. 1st Aid de Camp—the endorsed there is no law that authorises the granting of Land to the Corps called the Legion of Franks War Department— Bounty Land-Office 20 August 1828.— Then a paper purporting that Robert Taylor returns the Discharge of Pierre Gedeon, and informs him that he is not entitled to Military bounty Land, Congress having authorised it only for soldiers in the regular line this paper is addressed to P Gedeon care of Abraham Moor Esqr Boston; but Mr Bowen supposes that this paper was written by Abraham Moor himself—and takes it much to heart— Finally a Letter from Mr W. Gordon to Mr Bowen himself dated Bounty Land Office 10 March 1830 informing him that this claim and all others like it are inadmissible, and now after the lapse of ten years Mr Bowen renews the claim for his land— I told him that if attainable at all it could only be by petition to Congress; and if he would prepare such a petition, and send it to me, with his assignment or power from Gédéon, I would present the Petition at the Commencement of the Session—but he was desirous that I should first ascertain at the War department whether he may not obtain the Land without petition to Congress, which I promised to do, and to write the result to him at Brighton— Mr John Wingate Thornton, a student of the Senior Class at the Law School at Cambridge, and a Cousin of Miss Cutts came this afternoon to visit her, and took tea with us— And Miss Brigham brought a subscription paper for a present of a gown and a Study-chair for Mr Lunt— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— And my wife with Mrs Charles and Miss Cutts went to visit the Fair and exhibition of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanic Association at Quincy Hall, where they met Isaac P. Davis and Charles Bradbury,—and with which they were highly gratified— The weather from being warm last Evening and this morning, cleared with a cold Northwester in the course of this day— In the month of May I had thrown an Orange which I had brought in my pocket from Mr N Biddle’s at Andalusia, into a hole which I dug in the garden near the nursery gate, and covered it over with Earth— About a month since there shot up from it Orange trees— Foreseeing that if left there this Night they would be killed by the frost, I had them taken up, put into a flower-pot, and brought into the house and committed to the care of Mrs Kirke— Frederick A. Whitney and Jos. Pierce Cranch were here this Eve.
5. IV: Saturday.

Last night and this morning the sky was clearer than I ever saw it in any part of Europe, and more remarkably so than I had ever observed it in this hemisphere— The multitude and brightness of the Stars was dazzling, and I specially remarked this morning the waning crescent of the moon, the last of her days but one, before the change, with a distinct luminous line round her whole disk. The Star horizontally West about 3 Sun’s disks from Sirius, and that perpendicular about the same distance above Procyon seemed almost of the first magnitude— I had intended to be quite industrious this day, and began a Lecture to be delivered before the Braintree Lyceum; but nearly the whole day was taken from me— Mr George Alexander Otis came out, in great trouble about a very severe critique upon his translation of the Tusculan of Cicero, which the critic says will be satisfactory neither to those who do nor to those who do not read the original— The criticism is illiberal, and evidently unfriendly, and two or three passages in which Mr Otis had made slight mistakes of the meaning of Cicero, are selected with invidious sagacity, as warrants for general condemnation. Mr Otis has, and left with me Letters more than commendatory from W. H. Prescott, H. G. Otis, Daniel Webster, President Josiah Quincy, Dr George Parkman, F. W. P. Greenwood, William Sullivan, President F. Wayland, and even one from Dr John G. Palfray the Editor of the North-American Review to set off against the cross grain of this one censor, and he is agonizing for one from me which will not avail him so much as a straw. He is a strange compound of a man; and yet, one of a numerous tribe—Studious—laborious, pertinacious, immeasurably self-conceited and vain, thinking himself at least equal to Cicero and Botta because he has translated them, professing entire self-satisfaction yet ravenous of applause; pouring forth fulsome adulation without stint and longing for the most nauseous sycophancy in return— I promised to write him a Letter but I know it will bitterly disappoint him, for I have already praised him as much as with a clear conscience I could but he must have more, and I shall dash it with qualifications and friendly counsels which will turn it all to wormwood— I said to him fas est et ab hoste doceri, and advised him to revise the passages censured by the reviewer, and the whole work— He left with me also his manuscript revisal of Dr Franklin’s translation of Cicero upon Old age— This afternoon a young Virginian named John F. Heath a Senior Sophister at Harvard University came to see me, from mere curiosity, and brought me a Letter of Introduction from his uncle Francis C Rives the member of the House of Representatives of the United States. His Letter is dated Boston 25. Septr. but he did not think it worth his while to come and see me himself. I took the young man up to Charless house to see the prospects, and Charles remembered to have seen him at the examinations of his Class, in Greek He declined staying to tea— Dr Holbrook was here this afternoon to see Louisa C Smith who is very unwell— Charles here this Evening.
6. IV:30— Sunday
Sun rose 6:2. Set 5:36. Day 11 hours 34 minutes—
White frost— Fahrenheit at Sun rise 30.

Mr Lunt preached this morning from 2. Samuel 24.24. [“]And the king said unto Araunah, Nay; but I will surely buy it of thee at a price.— neither will I offer, burnt offerings unto the Lord my God, of that which doth cost me nothing. So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen, for fifty shekels of silver.”— The duty of supporting religious institutions by pecuniary contributions was the natural subject of this discourse, not precisely seasonable in point of time, from a cause of which Mr Lunt himself was unconscious the subscription going round to make up a small present to him in token of approbation for his centurial sermons— His afternoon text was from Proverbs 17.17 [“]A friend loveth at all times”—and the Sermon, a sensible Dissertation upon the duties and pleasures of friendship. He gave notice that from this time for the winter, the morning bell for meeting would be at half past ten, and that of the afternoon at a quarter before two— We had visits after the service from Mr Charles Harrod of New-Orleans, with Mrs Harrod, and Elizabeth C Adams.— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— In my anxiety to keep this Diary up to the day I forgot the usual reading of one of Dr Parker’s Sermons— I have heretofore noticed my correspondence with Mr James H. Hackett upon Shakespear’s Tragedy of Hamlet— I this day received a letter from him dated LondonAugust 1839. on opening of which the first thing that met my eye was as I thought my own Letter to him of 19. February last from Washington, but which on examination and on reading his Letter I found was a lithographic copy of mine, which he says he had taken, because he had lent the original to so many of his numerous friends and acquaintance that it had been nearly used up— The lithographic copy of my Letter is so perfect a facsimile that if it had been presented to me as the original I should have acknowledged it without an instant of hesitation as my own, but for a notification at the bottom of the 4th. page in characters so small as to be scarcely legible with the naked eye that it was lithographed for Mr Hackett. And with this Letter there was a packet containing three lithographic portraits of himself—one in his own person, engraved for the New-York Mirror in 1833—one in the character of Monsieur Mallet, and one in the character of Falstaff in Henry the 4th. the only part in which I ever saw Mr Hackett—and the Tragedy of Hamlet published on the 1st. of August 1839. being part 10. one of the numbers of a pictorial Edition of Shakspere now in the process of publication— It is a beautiful work, with 26 engravings all illustrative of various passages, in the play; and including views of Elseneur; of the Palace of Rosenberg and Cronberg Castle, all peculiarly interesting to me, from the associations left on my mind by the few days that I passed in the Harbour of Elseneur in September 1809— Mr Hackett in his Letter mentions also that he has very recently heard of an analysis by me of the tragedy of Othello, and enquires where he can procure it— This extension of my fame is more tickling to my vanity than it was to be elected President of the United States. I pray God to forgive me for it; and to preserve me from falling in my last days into the dotage of self adulation— There are indications enough of the censorial Spirit of the world, and still more of its indifference, if I will but take note of them.
7. V. Monday.
Sun rose 6:3: Set 5.34. Day 11 hours 31 minutes.
White frost. Fahrenheit at Sunrise 32

The Season has so far changed that the garden, nursery and Orchard no longer offer temptations to a waste of time in them. I am gathering the last of my peaches, of which we have had this Season a great abundance and variety from seedlings of my own planting, and the Baldwin Apples from Medford, of which I have from one tree the first fruits this year, worthy of being exhibited at the horticultural exhibition— I planted this afternoon about 100 peach stones in the 8 new seminary rings— I have mislaid the 4th. volume of Grahame’s history of the United States which I had borrowed of my Son, and am now reading the third report from the select Committee of the British House of Commons on Postage; which Mr Henry Gassett of Boston sent me in a London weekly newspaper called the Spectator. The report recommends an entire revisal of the system of raising revenue from postage upon a plan proposed in a pamphlet of Rowland Hill the main object of which is to reduce the rate of postage of Letters to one penny for a single Letter weighing half an ounce, without regard to distance throughout the kingdom; increasing the postage by one penny for each additional half ounce, requiring always payment in advance, and abolishing all franks. This system is said to have been carried into effect by act of Parliament in Great Britain and Mr Gassett thinks it would be advisable to introduce it here— I received an Address delivered at Amherst, before the literary Societies of that College, on the 27th of August last, by Daniel D. Barnard; an admirable discourse, in which the promise of applause after I am dead is itself one of the highest honours I ever received— I wrote this afternoon a page of my Lecture for the Braintree Lyceum, and read, part of the Tragedy of Hamlet and of the Commentaries on it, in the copy received yesterday from Mr Hackett— I return to the case of the Africans of the Amistad— Emancipator of 19. Septr. 1839— Notice in the Spanish Newspaper at New-York, Noticios de Ambos Mundos—translated in New-York American of 11 Septr. of the case-claim of the Spanish Minister Calderon de la Barca for the restitution of the vessel, Cargo and Slaves— Articles from the New-York Evening Post and New-York Evangelist on Piracy— Lewis Tappan’s Letter. Letters from Genl. Smith Rufus Choate—Ellis Gray Loring and John Jay. Reference to 4. Peters condensed Reports 632. concerning the decision in Palmers case. Emancipator of 26 Septr 1839— Letter of E. Sears Master of Schooner Eveline of Kingston which met and communicated with the Amistad. 19. Augt.— Letter from Lewis Tappan Hartford 17. 18. 19. 20. 21. Septr. Report of proceedings of the Circuit Court U.S. at Hartford upon two processes of Habeas Corpus to liberate the Africans taken in the Amistad— Notice that the decision of the Court was against their liberation— Emancipator of 3. October 1839 Decision of the Circuit Court US that the prisoners are lawfully in the custody of the US District Court, which is adjourned to 3d. Tuesday of November at Hartford.
8. V. Tuesday

With the exception of one hour lost by the tardiness of my rising from bed this day was so occupied, as I could wish every day to be. As little of its time was wasted in idleness as I can hope any of its successors will be, and in hearing the children read in reading a scrap of the British report on postage, a fragment of the commentary on Hamlet the newspaper unwelcome accounts of the Maryland elections; especially in the loss of that of John P. Kennedy and the two most disastrous fires within one week at Philadelphia and New-York and in writing a page of this diary and two of the Lecture for the Braintree Lyceum, the day till evening twilight was consumed without interruption; and I spent the Evening with all my family at Charles’s House on the hill, where we met Mr and Mrs. Lunt and her Sister Mrs Robbins who is on a visit to her— I cursorily looked over the numbers of the common School Journal a periodical published twice a month by the Secretary of the board of education of this Commonwealth Horace Mann— But that which most perplexes me is the case of the Africans captured in the Amistad and the proceedings in the Circuit and District Courts of the United States relating to them— There are two decisions of the Circuit judge Thomson to be renewed. 1. That the Circuit Courts of the United States have no jurisdiction, to try the crime of piracy committed in foreign vessels—and 2 That the Courts of the United States are bound to consider foreign Slaves as property liable to be claimed by foreigners, to whom they must be delivered up— For the first of these decisions he cited that of the U.S. in Palmers case 3. Wheaton’s reports 610. and 4. Peters condensed Reports 352 and in page 367. there is a note of sundry cases decided in the Courts of the United States relative to Piracy.— For his second decision he cited the case of the Antelope reported 10. Wheaton 66. and 6. Peters condensed Reports 30 but in the case of United States vs Smith 5. Wheaton 153 and Marshall on the Constitution 598. The Supreme Court decided that Smith and part of a Buenos Ayres privateer who mutinied, seized another privateer, put to sea without documents or commission, and took and robbed a Spanish vessel on the high Seas were punishable as Pirates under the act of Congress of 3. March 1819—an act which was indeed repealed by that of 15. May 1820, but with the provision of a substitute for it— U.S. vs Pirates 5. Wheaton 192— The Act of 3. March 1819. extends in terms to foreign ships &c 11. Wheaton 1. 3. Mason 116— U.S. vs Tully et al. 1. Gallison 247— The Josefa Secunda— 5. Wheaton 338. 4 Peters condensed Reports 672.— Almeida vs certain Slaves 5. Hall’s American Law Journal 459— US vs. Pirates 4 Peters condensed Reports p 624—and especially 628 and 630. and 632—and 635. In the case of the Antelope 6. Peters 40. C.J. Marshall says the court are divided, and no principle settled.
9. IV:15. Wednesday
Ride to Scituate— S. A. Turner’s. Quincy.

I had promised Mr Samuel Adams Turner of Scituate that I would go and take a farmer’s dinner with him this day, and examine the spot where they are desirous of obtaining an appropriation from Congress for the improvement of their harbour— Accordingly at half past seven O’Clock this morning, I took Charles’s four wheel chaise, with one of my horses and Thomas to drive me; stopped at Mr Minott Thayers and told him that if convenient to the people of Braintree I would fix upon the 24th of this month at 3 O’Clock in the afternoon to deliver the Lecture which I have promised to their Lyceum— I travelled over the Braintree and Weymouth and then the Scituate Turnpike and as I had promised reached Mr Turner’s house precisely at ten; about 16 miles— I then went with Mr Turner in his Chaise about 4 miles farther to the harbour which is low and small— There I met Mr Cumings Jenkins the Inspector of the Port, Captain Ezekiel Jones, Captain of a Revenue Cutter, but upon furlough being out of health Mr John Beal, and a Mr Young inhabitants of the town— We stopped perhaps a quarter of an hour at Mr Jenkins’s house and partook of a luncheon with a temperate glass of cold water— We then rode back to Mr Turner’s, Mr Jenkins and Captain Jones being of the dinner party— On the way Mr Turner pointed out to me the course where they were desirous of having a Canal opened, to keep the channel of the river sufficiently deep— But there is another project petitioned for by certain inhabitants of Marshfield, which these Gentlemen, particularly Mr Turner thought would be rather injurious than beneficial to Scituate. Mr Turner gave me a map upon which he marked the line where they wished the canal to run— Mrs Turner, and his daughter, a young woman from 18 to 20, were at table— The dinner was plentiful and good.— There was white wine of which Mr Turner and I took each one glass and no one else any. I called twice to visit the Revd. Samuel J. May, a next door neighbour of Mr Turner, but he was gone to Plymouth— Mr Turner shewed me a large printed sheet of the descendants from Humphrey Turner who settled at Scituate in 1626. a numerous family— He was a large Landholder—but his descendants still hold all the lands that he possessed and more— We rode by the house and farm which was the residence of the worthy judge William Cushing in his lifetime— Mr Turner said that forty years ago, when he was a boy seven years of age, the judge had his house new painted and the fences round it renewed; and he then thought it the most magnificent mansion in the world. But he had since then seen more splendid places. It looks now, much in decline, and somewhat dilapidated— It belongs to a nephew of the judge, a lawyer at Boston named Elwyn— Mr Turner told me also of Judge Nathan Cushing, and of Doctor Cushing Otis, old acquaintances of mine, and both of whom lived and died at Scituate— They seemed under some apprehension that their Light house would be suppressed, and thought the was a project for erecting one on the Minot’s or Cohasset rocks— Soon after 3. O’Clock, I left Mr Turner with his friends, and returned to Quincy by the same way that I had gone. I reached home at 6. P.M. Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
10. V. Thursday.

Deacon Spear called here this morning and proposed to me to go with my Son and him this afternoon to view my wood lot at the foot of Penn’s Hill, where he has been persuading me to sell the standing wood— I agreed to go with him, but a sprinkling of rain which came on just at 3. O’Clock, the time when we had to go, prevented him from coming and the party was postponed— Frederick Hardwick came with a small bill for fencing between his yard and my Quincy Meadow. Seven years ago in 1832. as I was passing by there, he stopped me, and shewing me that the fence was somewhat dilapidated, offered to have the division between us measured and to have the whole fence repaired if I would pay half the cost, to which I agreed and thought no more about it— Some four or five years afterwards be stopped me again and reminded me of the old debt which I had always been ready to pay at his call— This day he brougt me a bill for 2. dollars and a half, and 1. dollar and 10 cents for seven years for interest, and half of 1 dollar 50 cents for measuring the ground— I paid the bill without asking a question or starting an objection— He could have no possible claim to the interest; and very little to the principal, upon which I think he has not spent the value of half a dollar—but here was wherewithal to make an argument and a dispute, which I would always give double the money to avoid— In questions of small amount with persons of small means, it is policy to submit to opposition rather than get into a quarrel— Hardwick told me he had now a son dangerously ill of a bilious fever, and that last December he lost a Son, sixteen years of age, found dead in his bed one morning, with no other warning than a slight head ache the night before— I could not cavil about a dollar with a man, who could tell such a piteous tale with a dry eye— I had 30 seedling Apple trees taken out of the St. Germain Pear-tree bed in the garden, and set out in the Orchard behind the house— I sowed the seeds of these trees in 1834 and 1835. and they have encroached so much upon the kitchen garden ground that I must now remove them to leave space for raising vegetables for the table. Many of them are very fine trees, but what will be their fate in their new habitations I shall perhaps not know, or if I do, only to my disappointment. My plantations of peaches have indeed this year yielded abundant and excellent fruit, and although seven or eight of them have broken down by the violence of the gale or by the weight of their own exuberance I have yet numbers in full bearing and younger trees of excellent promise and of every successive year to the present time— My transplanted and budded apple-trees are just beginning to bear— Of the Ash, the while elm, the button wood and sundry kinds of Oaks, and the white Maple— I have raised enough to know that if I had thirty years of life before me I could raise forests which would more than repay all the time and toil and cost— But this is all— Charles his wife and two sons dined with us— He spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s.
11. IV:30. Friday—

Captain Joshua Drew of Duxbury was here this morning with a petition to have refunded to him a penalty of 253 dollars levied upon him by the Collector of New-Orleans on the 6th. of April 1838. for a supposed violation of the Act of Congress relating to the returns of Seamen; because on his return to New-Orleans, from a voyage to Liverpool, his crew did not answer to the names by which they had shipped. Captain Drew was here last November, before I went to Washington, upon this same business; but he had not then his petition ready nor has had it until now. I took it, together with a certificate from the Consul at Liverpool, and two depositions, and promised to present the Petition at the Meeting of Congress in December. Captain Drew told me he was intending to sail next week upon another voyage to New-Orleans, and thence to Europe—expecting to be absent nearly or quite a year. Mr Minott Thayer, and Mr Hollingsworth of Braintree came to say that they had agreed that my address to the Lyceum shall be delivered at Mr Storrs’s meeting house in Braintree at 3. O’Clock in the afternoon, and Mr Thayer invited me to dine with him at one— Mr Thayer was excessively curious to know what would be the subject of my discourse, and wanted to give some notice of it—I told him I hardly knew myself, but believed that it would be on the subject which he had suggested to me—Education— And if it was—I should treat it in a manner somewhat different from that in which it is usually considered— Mr Hollingsworth asked me to shew him Mount Wollaston which I did— He said there was a hill in Braintree called by that name. This must have been some fancy indulged since the division of the town, to give the present town of Braintree a colour of claim to having been the spot of the original settlement of the town— Captain J. A. L. Norman was here to renew his patriotic and benevolent importunities for the establishment of the Dade Institute, in the Territory of Florida, with which he was troublesome to me and others last winter at Washington— This Dade Institution, already incorporated by the territorial Legislature of Florida, and of which Captain Norman is President, is a plan for establish an University, conjointly with the erection of a sepulchral monument in honour of Captain Dade and all the other officers and soldiers of the United States who have perished in the Florida War— The application to Congress is for a Township of Land— Captain Norman intimated a wish for a Letter from me to President Quincy, recommending to him to appoint a meeting of the Students of Harvard University to pass spirited Resolutions of commendation to the project of the Dade institution which I declined— Mrs Edward Miller was here with her Sister Mrs. Spooner; and Dr Holbrook to visit Louisa C. Smith, who is much indisposed— Charles went to Boston—and his wife with Mary and Miss Cutts— All returned to dine.
12. IV:30 Saturday
Boston. Dinner at Abbott Lawrence’s— Quincy.

I went into Boston this morning with Thomas, in Charles’s chaise and one of my own horses. I called immediately at Dr George Parkman’s, but he was not at home— I then went to the City Council chamber in the old Townhouse; where I found the Mayor, Samuel A. Elliot the Clerk of the city Council Samuel F. M’Cleary and several other members of the City Government— I examined several volumes, of the town records, and particularly those of the Births marriages and deaths. I found entries of the birth of the four daughters of William Ting as follows.

row.cell: Eliza Daughter of William Ting and Elizabeth his wife born

div.p: (See diary of 16 and 22. Augt. last for the dates of the baptism of them all)

I found entries also of the birth of nine children of Edward Ting and Mary his wife. Of all these the only one of peculiar interest to me is Anna, the wife of Thomas Shepard mother of Anna Shepard, wife of Daniel Quincy, and Grandmother of my great grand father John Quincy— I was much disappointed to find no further memorial of any of the Boylston family; but I found numerous entries of the births of the name of Adams, having apparently no relation to Henry Adams of Mount Wollaston and Braintree— There are four children of Alexander and Mary Adams from 1645 to 1656. and three of Nathaniel and Mary Adams from 1653 to 1657.— There are returns from John Mills, Clerk of the writs, at Braintree, and from Henry Adams of the same office at Medfield— The marriage of Norton Quincy with Martha Salisbury 12. Feby. 1746. I found also records of the original grants of lands at Mount Wollaston to individuals 27. 11. 1639—and 29. day 12. Mo. Feby 1640. specially to Henry Adams, for ten heads 40 acres at a rate of 3 shillings per Acre— I was upwards of two hours there but yet was obliged to leave much of my examination unfinished— I called then a second and third time on Dr George Parkman, who at last came home, and I shewed him the Letter of Mr Hackett to me, with the lithographed fac simile of mine to him, at the perfect imitation of which he was surprized— He returned me the precious Letter of Mr Hackett to me, and gave me a printed copy of each of my essays on certain characters of Shakespear which I had addressed to him— He accompanied me to the House of Mr Abbott Lawrence where I dined with the Trustees of the Agricultural Society. The company—P. C. BrooksChapman, H. Codman, I. P. Davis, Governor Everett, Mr Finney, B. Guild, Revd. S. K. Lathrop—Mr and Mrs Lawrence, their Son and daughter. Chevalier Norden, Chargé d’Affaires from Sweden, Josiah Quincy junr. John Pickering, Dr John Warren, John Welles, Govr T. L. Winthrop and his son Robert C. Winthrop and Mr Wolcott, Mrs Lawrence’s brother J. P. Bigelow came in after dinner— I had a dark ride home—but reached it safe about seven O’Clock.
13. V. Sunday

Yesterday Morning about 4. O’Clock I was awakened by the ringing of Bells, and on rising found it was a fire blazing in the direction of Quincy point, which proved to be the English goods Store of Mr John Whitney—which had been broken open, robbed and then set on fire— His loss is heavy, and said to be without insurance— He is a very worthy, respectable man, whose neighbours sympathise with him in his misfortune— Dr Francis Parkman preached here this morning from Philippians 2.5. [“]Let this mind be in you which was also in Christ Jesus: 6. Who being in the form of God— 8 and being found in fashion as a man, he humbled himself and became obedient unto death, even the death of the cross— 9. Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name”— The Discourse was upon the excellent Christian virtue of humility—but this is a much controverted passage, and Dr Parkman omitted from his text part of the 6th. and the whole of the 7th. verse— The words in the common English Bible thought it not robbery to be equal with God, Charles Thomson translates did not think it robbery to be like God— Dr Parkman dined with us, and preached in the afternoon from 1. Corinthians 15.33. [“]Be not deceived— Evil communications corrupt good manners.[”]— This discourse was introduced with some account of the peculiar character of Saint Paul’s preaching, his learning, his acquaintance with the Hebrew Law, and the Grecian Literature, and his address in always adapting the arguments of his speeches to the feelings and prepossessions of his auditory— The Sermon however, upon the dangers of evil communications, was eloquent, pathetic and peculiarly adapted to the young— Among the cruel and dreadful consequences of evil communications, he touched upon those which led to infidelity; and related an illustration of it the case of an aged woman upon whose death bed he attended; and who in bitterness of Soul told him that she found it utterly impossible to form a conception either of the Love or the fear of God— There was also in this discourse an affecting and elaborate description of the process of depravation as it takes place in an unguarded young man going from a country village into a populous city and falling into bad company— Mr E. Price Greenleaf and Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— Having omitted last Sunday to read a Sermon of Dr Parker’s, I read this Evening two—the 11th. on Solicitude for the revival of Religion; which he considers not with much favour; as an indication that the revival has been preceded by criminal neglect—and the 12th. upon amusements—preached at the annual thanksgiving of 1828. His sentiments in favour of innocent amusements are liberal.
14. V. Monday.
Boston— Probate Court— G. Fuller— Quincy.

Heavy rain, almost the whole day— But I had promised to meet Mr George Fuller at the probate Office in Boston this morning, and went accordingly with Thomas in Charles’s Chaise and one of my own horses— I called first at the probate Office, then at Charles’s Office for a few minutes where I met Mr Spooner; then again at the probate Office where Mr Fuller shortly afterwards came in— I presented my third account as Administrator de bonis non with the will annexed of Thomas Boylston— I presented to the judge all the documents in my possession, shewing the proportion of the sum recovered for the old accounts of the Cargo of the fair lady, to that which is equitably due to the Estate of Governor Gill, and the Representatives of his Nephew. There is no evidence whatever of the right of Governor Gill to any part of the money except that which is produced by me; and neither Mr Fuller nor the judge could even suggest the precise amount to which the representatives of the late Moses Gill have an equitable claim— But when I suggested that the note from the late Moses Gill should be deducted from the amount, Mr Fuller said he supposed that note must be presented to him ad administrator, and the judge said that he did not think he had any authority to direct its allowance— I enquired whether having recovered the money not only as administrator of Thomas Boylston, but as attorney with a full power of the late Moses Gill, I had not such a lien upon it as would enable me to reserve so much of the sum recovered as would enable me to pay the note to Mrs Boylston— The judge hesitated; and Mr Fuller said the heirs of the late Moses Gill were under an impression, that he had been wronged— That at the time when the note is dated he was non compos mentis— And he said he himself had believed that Gill was then under guardianship— In this however he added he found he had been mistaken— I said I had never heard a surmise or whisper that Mr Gill was under guardianship, or I never should have received from him a power of attorney— The judge finally proposed that we should fix upon some other than a probate day, and when he would not be disturbed by the business of other persons, and when he might deliberately consider the whole subject. We accordingly agreed upon to-morrow week, the 22d. of this month at 10. O’Clock— I then called at Mr Ellis Gray Loring’s Office— He told me that he should very shortly reply to my Letter; but that he had only yesterday received answers from Mr Sedgwick and Mr Staples, to the enquiries he had addressed to them in consequence of my Letter, and their answers did not entirely agree together— As to the act of 15. May 1820. he was informed there had been a decision by Judge Baldwin in the U.S. Circuit Court of Pennsylvania, that this act gave no jurisdiction to the Courts of the United States in cases of Piracy committed on board of a foreign-vessel— I came home to dinner under a heavy rain, which continued till Night— Call at Charles’s about Sunset.
15. IV:30. Tuesday

Copious, but moderate rain, all Night and the whole of this day.— This was the day of the autumnal exhibition at Harvard University, which I had been summoned to attend, as a member of the Committee of the board of Overseers— I had intended to have gone into Boston with Charles; and thence in the hourly omnibus to Cambridge;—but the weather and a severe cold prevented him from going to Boston, and I concluded to confine myself to the house and write— My grand-child Fanny was unwell, and confined this Evening to her mother’s chamber— Louisa C. Smith cannot leave hers, and was this day notwithstanding the storm visited by Dr Holbrook— I went at the dusk of evening up the hill to see Charles and his wife, confined with Colds— I retrieved one day of arrears in this diary, still leaving two— Wrote two pages of a wretched address upon Education to be delivered next week at Braintree, and in the evening wrote a Letter to Doctor Andrews of Newbury-Port, to send with the Letters from Edward Boylston’s Letters to Edward Wigglesworth which he had lent me— I received a day or two since, a long Letter from the Revd. Andrew Bigelow of Taunton, enclosing, a slip from a late Boston Courier in which is published a Letter from Mr Bigelow to Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn, respecting a discovery by Mr Joseph Dixon of that town, of an art of transferring copies of prints, engravings, and books by a lithographic process, similar to the taking duplicates of manuscripts with a copying press—upon which however it is a great improvement, inasmuch as it takes off a perfect copy, without any apparent injury to the original, and by the means of the lithographic stone, can multiply the number of copies ad libitum— Mr Bigelow sent me also two specimens of this mode of transfer—one of a page from an arabic grammar, and the other of a card of Joseph Gillott the Steel pen-maker— In the Letter to Genl. Dearborn, there is an extract from a Paris public journal of the present year announcing as a new discovery in the arts precisely the same invention by a French printer named Dupont— But Mr Dixon claims his invention as having been published in 1832.— I had already received some weeks since a Letter from Mr John Marston of Taunton, with a page of the Arabic Grammar transferred by the same Mr Dixon—and the lithographic copy of my Letter ofFebruary last to Mr Hackett sent me by him from London appears to have been made by the same or a similar process— I have also received a Letter from Mr Dijah Bowen at Brighton enclosing a Letter to him of 5. October 1839. (of 29. Jany 1830) from Peter Gedeon, authorising him to recover the Land to which Gedeon supposed himself entitled; and to dispose of it for the benefit of his wife— This is no competent power, and will not serve as an authority for a petition to Congress— Another claim perhaps more likely to succeed, and certainly as equitable, is commended to my care, by Dr. Nathan Hayward of Plymouth in a Letter of 7. Octr. for the extension of the benefit of the Pension Laws to the warriors who served in the Indian Wars, from 1783 to 1795— He was at that time a Surgeon in the Army.
16. V. Wednesday

Venus morning star—conjunction with [symbols] the 5th Rising at 5 and coming into my chamber, I saw Venus shining bright, and about 5. minutes risen— The sky cleared away last evening after Sunset, and the Night was serene— Charles went in to Boston, and returned to dine— Also his wife and Mary in the Carriage. The Misses Crowninshield also sent from Boston a Carriage for Miss Cutts, who went to pay them a visit of some days. Alpheus Spear came and settled for the last quarter’s rent of the Mount Wollaston farm, and William Spear to propose a ride this afternoon to the Penn’s hill grove which I accepted— Mr Wolcott the Minister of the Episcopal Church in this Town, came to ask my assistance to obtain an appointment as a Cadet at the West Point Academy— He has one Son there already; but he entered as from the State of Connecticut of which Mr Wolcott is a native—he has not yet been two years here— I told him I would have the name of his Son entered at the War Department, on the list of Candidates for admission at the Academy; but that he could not expect admission till the present Cadet from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, Zealous B. Tower shall have got through and been graduated— I told him also that it might be an objection to his admission that he has a brother already there; but of that I could not speak with certainty— Mr Wolcott said he had yet a younger son whom he proposed to send to some college. He would have sent this one, but he himself was anxiously desirous of going to West-Point— Mr Lunt was here and returned several of the books which he had borrowed while preparing his centennial Sermons.— He spoke of the town-meeting last evening, called to consider the expediency of celebrating on the 25th. of next May, the second centennial anniversary since the incorporation of the town of Braintree— It has been turned into an affair of party— There was a meeting called by notice in the Quincy Patriot last Saturday, of those opposed to the incurring of any expense for the celebration— The fear was that I should be chosen to deliver the Address. They finally by a vote of 28 to 22 appointed a Committee of 7. to confer with Committees from the towns of Braintree and Randolph, upon the expediency of holding a joint celebration by the three towns.— Charles his wife and children dined with us— At half past 3. Deacon Spear came with his Carry all and one horse in which he, and Charles and I—and Charles’s boys, John and Charles went to the pine hill grove—open examination of which we found about one third of the trees had been cut down, and carried away; it is impossible to ascertain by whom I found a few black and white oak acorns, and a few shagbark walnuts; and I determined to have the whole grove close shaven to the ground— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us.
17. IV:30. Thursday

Louisa C. Smith is still much indisposed, and confined to her chamber where Dr Holbrook visits her every other day; and Mary’s daughter Georgiana-Frances is also very unwell, occasioning great anxiety to her mother, and not less to me— The diseases of children are more deeply affecting to their relatives than those of persons full grown; for in addition to our sympathy with their sufferings we cannot but painfully feel for their helplessness. For several months past Mary has repeatedly consulted a female physician in Boston by the name of Hunt, for the complaint of her daughter in the ear, which affects her with deafness— I advised her last Evening to consult Dr Reynolds, who keeps an ear-infirmary, and has an established reputation of skill, in the treatment of diseases of that organ— Mr James Newcomb was here this morning with a subscription paper gotten up for Captain John Whitney, who lost his ware house and almost his entire stock in trade last week by fire, and without a dollar of insurance— Mr Newcomb told me also of the proceedings at the town meeting the evening before last— The party turn given to the proceedings is upon a project plan’d last Summer and conducted under the superintendence of George Bancroft the Collector of the Customs at Boston a supple tool of President Van Buren, and who by a double process carries on this dirty intrigue against me, and fawns upon me like a Spaniel. The opposition to the centennial celebration, is from a fear that my Address would propitiate favour to me among the people, and make it more difficult to displace me at the next ensuing election. But it is extremely doubtful to me, whether I can or ought to accept the appointment to deliver the address even if it should be proposed to me, for it must be delivered towards the close of the next Month of May, in the busiest days of the next Session of Congress— I received nearly a month since a Letter from Frederick Hall, corresponding Secretary of the American Historical Society at Washington, with a resolution of that Society, inviting me to prepare and deliver a discourse for the Society, at some time during the ensuing Session of Congress; and he also informs me that I have been chosen the President of that Society— I am ashamed to say I have not yet answered that Letter— Three days since I received a Letter from George L. Curry, President of the Mechanic Apprentice’s Library Association, in behalf of the Lecture Committee of that Society, inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them on the 7th. or 14th. of November at Boston— This Society consists exclusively of Mechanics Apprentices, numbers about 300 members; and the profits of their Lectures, are for increasing their library of 2000 volumes.— The next day, I received a Letter from John G. Whittier at Philadelphia, informing me, that the Female Anti-Slavery Society of that City propose to hold a fair in the latter part of the 12th. month, the proceeds to be applied to the furtherance of the Anti-Slavery cause in that State— And they think of publishing a small volume of poetry for which they ask a contribution from me— None of these Letters yet answered.
18. V. Thursday.

Charles went to Boston this morning— And his wife with Mary in the Carriage— They all returned to dine, and Charles without his wife spent the Evening here— Louisa C. Smith and Fanny are yet very unwell, and a gloom is shed over the house— My garden has become an eye-sore to me, for Kirke has uprooted at least two hundred beautiful seedling trees fruit and forest, from 5 to ten years old, not one in twenty of which will survive the next summer— I have parted with them all with an aching heart, more than ever detesting all transplanted trees— Above all others I lament a beautiful American White Oak, nine years old, and about 9 feet high which was flourishing at the Western end of the garden next to my neighbour Beale’s house, and which I might have lived to see bear fruit— It is torn up by the roots, and though set out in Charles’s ground will never come to any thing and probably not even survive the Winter— I have barely lived to see what might be done by raising fruit and forest trees from the seed; and to see all my labours of twelve successive Summers scattered to the winds before my eyes— For this and the two preceding days I have been buckled down to incessant labour in the House. The arrears of the Diary are oppressive, and the Braintree Lecture upon education yet more so. I was engaged hours of this day in reading over the 15th. and 16th. chapters and other passages of Gibbon’s history.— I succeeded at last in despatching a Letter to the Revd. Dr. Andrews of Newbury-Port the collection of Letters from Edward Boylston to Edward Wigglesworth which he had lent me— I received a Letter from Miss Anna Louisa Morton of Boston informing me that finding herself straitened for subsistence she has undertaken to publish an annual of a new and rare character; and requesting me to furnish for it an article of prose, in my usual graceful style of light Articles— She has no objection to a poetic article in addition to the more acceptable prose; but will not be importunate— I received also a Letter from Mr William A. Russell corresponding Secretary of the Connecticut Alpha of the Phi Beta Kappa Society, informing me that on the report of a nominating committee, the Society had unanimously voted to request me to deliver the address at the general meeting of the Society in August next—and a very kind and urgent solicitation from Mr Denison Olmstead the President of the Society that I would comply with the invitation— There is not one of these applications that I can reject without pain. It would give me heart-felt satisfaction to accept them all— Impossible!
19. V. Saturday.

Heavy Rain great part of the night and all the morning of this day, with damp and sultry weather— I accomplished nothing but retrieving the arrears of this diary, and drawing towards the close of a Lecture enormously dull, upon Education to be delivered next Thursday afternoon, in Mr Storrs’s meeting house before the inhabitants of Braintree—a Corvée, from which I have not been able to escape; and which together with other exactions of the same kind, depress my Spirits, rob me of time which should be devoted to useful and pleasing studies, waste the small faculties which God has given me for better purposes, and gratify by weak compliance with unreasonable requests idle and foolish curiosity, by the most thankless of labours— This is my deliberate judgment— Yet I have not firmness inflexibly to resist every such application, and the first of my duties is neglected— I suffer my vanity to be wheedled by flattery into a hope that these Discourses will last, though no second Edition of any one of them has been called for, from the Oration at Quincy in 1831. to the Jubilee of the Constitution at New-York last April— I had intended to finish the one upon which I am now engaged to morrow; but am so entangled with it, that I fear I shall not be able to bring it to a close within one or two days more— I went this afternoon to the Quincy Stone bank—deposited the Bills received from Alpheus Spear, and made a draught for small bills— The Pennsylvania Bank of the United States, and all the Banks in Philadelphia have suspended Specie payments— The Banks of Baltimore, of the State of Delaware and of the District of Columbia have followed the example— So have those of Providence, Rhode-Island. Those of New-York and Boston have not—and have determined that they will not.— A Resolution which it appears to me they will not be able to carry through. On the morning upon which I received John G. Whittier’s Letter, I saw Venus, just risen dazzling bright as morning Star. The thought occurred to me of taxing her for some lines for the Philadelphia female Anti-Slavery Society, and I have elaborated them thus—
To the Morning Star— Seen rising 5. A.M— 16. October 1839.

lg.l: Bright Star of Morning! welcome to mine eyes!
More lovely, than at even-tide’s decay.
For now thou comest with the dawning ray;
And soon the glorious lord of light shall rise.
Anon his splendor shall emblaze the Skies:
And thy own flame in his shall melt away
But mingled with his radiance, thine shall play.
With lustre, though unseen, that never dies.
Oh! Morning Star, of Man’s immortal Soul!
When shall thy beams irradiate the pole.
Redeeming Earth from Midnight’s ebon sway?
Dispel the gloom of Slavery’s deadly shade—
Turn to the ploughshare Wars ensanguin’d blade;
And glow with promise of unclouded day?

div.p: 20. V. Sunday

A great change from warm and sultry weather last Night to severe cold and a Northeastern gale which swept the sky this day. Heard Mr Lunt, this morning from Isaiah 25:15.— “We have made a covenant with Death.” It was a funeral discourse on the occasion of the decease of two young men in this town in the course of the last week: the youngest son of the late Dr Phipps, about 19. of consumption, and Josiah Adams 3d. son of Josiah Adams junr. of Dysentery after 3 days illness aged 17. There was a mere transient allusion to these incidents, which scarcely admitted of more; although the untimely, sudden death of one of these youths and the lingering extinction of the other, furnished occasion for much of the common place lamentation upon the uncertainty and disappointments of human life. Mr Lunt did not take that course, but I have never heard a sermon from him, which left so little impression upon my mind as this upon the covenant with death. But his afternoon Sermon made amends—from Proverbs 4:7. [“]Wisdom is the principal thing, therefore get wisdom.” This was excellent, and practical— He remarked on the several different senses in which the word Wisdom is used in the Scriptures: tho’ he did not perhaps fully remark the difference between the sense in which it is used in the old and in the new Testament— The fear of the Lord in Solomon’s proverbs is the beginning of Wisdom— Solomon personifies her, and gives her the combined attributes of Piety and of Prudence— In the new Testament there is the wisdom from above and the wisdom from beneath— In its derivation it seems to be synonymous with knowledge; but Mr Lunt discriminated between them; as also between knowledge and the kindred properties of Learning and Genius.— His analysis of these several qualities was ingenious and judicious— After enlarging upon all the excellent uses of wisdom, and the duty of cultivating it he pointed out the several sources from which it is to be acquired—from the exercise of the reason—from self command—from the conversation of the wise—from experience—from prayer—from books, and especially from the Bible—concluding as he had begun by repeating his text— Wisdom is the principal thing—therefore get Wisdom— Returning home over the Hill from the afternoon service, I saw a ship coming into the harbour of Boston from Sea, under full sail and with a ten knot breeze. I read the 13th. Sermon of Dr. Parker, the second on Amusements; from which in this he seems to dissuade, though he appeared quite indulgent to them in the former one— He cautions young men and women against the excess of them with great fervour— I was unable as I feared to finish my Braintree Lecture though I toiled upon it, great part of the day— I have been obliged to examine the 9th. and 10th. Books of Robertson’s History of America— Much of Hutchinson’s first Volume— Winthrop’s Journal, and all the Colonial, Provincial and Commonwealth Laws upon the subject of Schooling and Education— Charles and his wife here this Evening.
21. IV:45. Monday.
Clear and cold night—frosty morning.

Mr Nathaniel Curtis was here, just as we finished our breakfast— He came upon the subject of the Note from the late Moses Gill, to Mrs. Alicia Boylston, of 5. Jany 1830. for 984 dollars 78 cents, with interest, which Mr Fuller Administrator on the Estate of Gill, declined allowing to be deducted from the amount payable to him on the account of Governor Gill’s claim, for that part of the proceeds of the Fair Lady’s cargo, which consisted of the 237. Casks of Whale Oil— Mr Curtis said that Mrs Fuller who was a very fine woman, had been over to Roxbury to see Mrs Boylston, and that he had taken her into Boston upon her return— That she had made a proposal for a compromise with regard to the note, which was that the principal should be deducted, without interest, and that he and Mrs Boylston, thought it would be most advisable to accept the proposition— I was of the same opinion, and said I thought it would be under all circumstances be no more than equitable to remit the interest— Mr. Curtis promised to go immediately, and see Mr Fuller, and to meet me with him to-morrow morning at the probate Office in Boston— The Revd. Mr Baynes a Clergyman from England, now preaching at the Orthodox Church in this Town, came with a Letter of Recommendation from Dr John Codman of Dorchester— Mr Baynes is a native of a village near Liverpool—was educated at a seminary under the direction of Doctors Boag and Bennet, was one year settled as a dissenting Minister at Douglas in the isle of Man, and six years at a chapel near Lancaster. He has been about a year and a half in this country, and preached for about three months at the Presbyterian church at Newbury Port— He comes with a warm Letter of Recommendation from Dr Raffles an eminent dissenting clergyman at Liverpool— Has been preaching six weeks at Quincy, and expects an invitation to settle here, which he proposes to accept— He mentioned to me that Drhad recently published in two 8vo. volumes a History of the Dissenters, which I have a strong curiosity to see— Mr Isaac Sanderson of Milton, manufacturer of the beach grass paper, called while we were at dinner, and left a variety of samples of his manufacture as Letter paper, folding paper, pasteboard, paper hangings for rooms, with the dried raw material of the grass—a sort of wool into which it is spun, and of small rope into which it is twisted— He left his card; but as we were at dinner did not come in— Mr Jonathan French the Schoolmaster, sent four of his Girls here with a note, requesting, if I had a miniature collection of engraved portraits of the Presidents of the United States, I would lend them to be copied by his pupils. I desired them to say to him that I had them not; but a doubt occurred to me, whether the consumption of time by the pupils in copying these miniature portraits of the Presidents, must not necessarily encroach upon the far more profitable accomplishments of correct reading of handsome hand writing, and of quick and accurate computation, with an intelligent comprehension and remembrance of the New-Testament— Charles here this Evening.
22. Tuesday. V.
Fahrenheit. 24. at Sunrise.
Boston— Probate Office— Quincy.

My morning was so much absorbed, as the last Evening had been, in reviewing the correspondence of Thomas Boylston, relating to the Fair Ladies Cargo, and in computations to ascertain the just amount of the proportion due to the representative of Governor Moses Gill, that I had scarcely time to breakfast before Charles came to take me in his Chaise into Boston— It was a bitter cold ride, though with a clear sky and bright Sun; and the 8 miles were run in three quarters of an hour— I called first at Charles’s Office, where I saw Mr Spooner; and at ten O’Clock went to the probate Office where successively came in the Judge of Probate, Mr Fuller, and Mr Nathaniel Curtis.— The judge settled the principle of the proportion, of the sum recovered as the proceeds of the Fair Lady’s Cargo, which will be due to Governor Moses Gills’ Estate, but in making the computations, could not come to the precise and specific sum— Mr Fuller did not accede to the proposition of compromise made by his wife. He said it was necessary for him to proceed cautiously— That others besides himself were interested in the transaction, and that he must not commit himself by chances to precipitation— He thought it necessary to have for the sanction of what he should do, the approbation of the judge of probate for the County of Worcester, from whom he received, his Letters of Administration. It was therefore proposed by the judge that his decree in this case should be postponed till next Saturday fortnight the 9th. of November; and in the meantime he gave an order that I should advertise in a public newspaper, for which I named the Boston Courier, the presentment of my Account of Administration. I then said that I had hitherto presented no claim of allowance to the Administrator, and should now leave it without argument to the judge to decide what it should be— Mr Fuller said he hoped I would consider that the heirs of the late Moses Gill were poor persons I said that as the agent and Attorney of Mr Gill I should make no charge at all— That my claim was for administration upon the Estate for which I had given bonds in the penalty of eighty thousand dollars— The judge said this was the most favourable statement of the claim, for the heirs of Gill that could be made—and would save them 100 dollars— After some consideration of the case he said that 600 dollars was the lowest sum that he could allow for the charge of administration, and asked if I should be satisfied with that— I said entirely—he fixed it therefore at that—and informed Mr Fuller that the proportion of it upon the Gill claim would be 46 dollars— I called again at Charles’s Office, and came home with him to dine— Charles and Louisa Foster were here this afternoon to see their Aunt Louisa C. Smith— And Charles and his wife were here in the Evening.
23. V:15. Wednesday.
Sun rose 6:22 Set 5.8. day 10 h. 46 m.

I brought my Braintree Lecture last evening to a close, so unsatisfactory to myself, that I wrote this morning an additional sentence with the purpose of making a more hopeful end; but I was no better satisfied with this than with what had gone before— The discourse is already too long, and I concluded to take no further trouble in the case; to deliver what I have written, and make up my mind for a failure— Deacon Spear was here and paid me 204 dollars for the note of Seth Spear of 20 June last given for my pew N. 74. in the Stone Temple—he paid in the Bills of the Quincy Stone Bank, which I immediately went and deposited there. I shall withdraw it all within a few days— The Banks in New-York and Boston hold out firm appearances of determination not to suspend their specie payments, but as this must depend on the will of others, and not their own, I can have no confidence in them— I saw the Sun rise this morning from the Southeast corner of Charles’s house; and my Chronometer agreed to the fraction of a minute with the American Almanac. Charles, his wife and children dined with us; but Mary was confined above with her daughter Fanny who is very alarmingly ill— Louisa C. Smith was able yesterday and this day for a short time to leave her chamber—convalescent. Alexander H. Everett and Leonard Jarvis took tea with us, and Mr Everett delivered at the town Hall, before the Quincy Lyceum a lecture upon the literary character of the Bible. Charles and I went with them to the Hall Mr Everett had delivered this Lecture two years ago at some college— It was then printed, and he had sent me a copy of it— After he finished this evening, he said to me, that it must be an old affair to me— I said I had read it with pleasure, renewed by his repetition of it now— He repeated it altogether from Memory, as is his usual practice, and that of his brother Edward. It was received with great and unremitted attention by a very crowded hall; two thirds of the auditors at least being women— After dropping us at my house, they proceeded to their own home at Roxbury— Miss Rachel Sampson the seamstress of 65 was all last week at Charles’s, and since yesterday morning has been with us.— Kirke has gathered the produce from the 24 hills of Rohan Potatoes, sown on the 15th. of last May, from two of the French and two American Potatoes given me by Mr Colman the State Commissioner of Agriculture— Several Oxen two or three weeks since were let into the enclosure where these Potatoes were planted, and the whole Night, had trampled down uprooted and devoured them. Yet there is at least a bushel from the French, and half that quantity from the American seed; all as large, and looking as well as the seed that was put into the ground.
24. IV:15 Thursday.
Braintree— Lecture on Education— Quincy.

Mr Southard and Mr Amos Lawrence were here just at noon; and as Charles and I were preparing to go to Braintree— Their visit was short— Mr Southard had come all the way from Jersey City, to deliver this Evening an introductory Lecture before the Boston Lyceum. He said that the thought had not occurred to him till after his arrival at Boston yesterday morning— That he had then asked himself what he came for, and he had answered it was because he was a fool— This same feeling has been one of my motives many times for declining to go hundreds of miles to deliver an Oration or Address— But I went this day with Charles to Braintree— We dined at one with Coll. Minott Thayer—and instead of two or three friends as I had expected there was a company of about 30 persons, and a dinner for at least 60. He said it was all the produce of his own farm; but there was Turkey, Mongrel Goose, Ducks, Ham Squab pie, a large variety of vegetables— Apple and cranberry sauce, and lemonade to drink, but neither wine nor cyder— Of the company there were Mr Storrs, Matthew Perkins, Hitchcock, and sundry others of the neighbourhood, all othordox clergymen, and Mr Blagden of Boston— Also Mr John Welles, Mr John P. Bigelow, and Mr Edward Brooks— Doctor Stephen Thayer, and Mr Hollingsworth I knew— The rest of the company were strangers— After a short and temperate dinner, we repaired to Mr Storrs’s Meeting house, where the services of the day were performed— First an Anthem—then a prayer by Mr Blagden, then another Anthem. Then a Lecture or Address by me upon Education—then a prayer by Mr Storrs—another Anthem and the benediction— I was an hour and twenty-five minutes in the delivery of my discourse; having omitted about as much as would have occupied twenty-five minutes more— The attention of the auditory was unremitted, and I witnessed no appearance of weariness or dissatisfaction— The house was just conveniently filled, but without being crowded, and there was room for more— At least two thirds of the auditory were women— After the service I went by invitation of Dr Storrs to his house, where I saw Mrs Storrs, and met several of the neighbouring clergymen and their wives.— Mr Storrs urged us to stay to tea, but I declined, and we reached home just at Sunset.— Found Charles’s wife at our house and Dr. Holbrook in attendance on Louisa C. Smith and Fanny— Her mother after much reluctance has consented to consult him, and the child is severely indisposed. Charles spent the Evening here, but his wife went home— The day was fine; of the precise kind commonly called Indian Summer.— My voice held out uncommonly well; but I found myself hoarse in the evening and much fatigued— The relief of a heavy burden removed was ample compensation for this, and at the close of Evening I retired with a grateful heart
25. V. Friday

Another Indian Summer day— I had no fire in my chamber but towards evening it grew so cold again that it was uncomfortable for writing. Mr Thomas Greenleaf and Mr Beale were here with new leases of Town lands to Solomon Hayden, andWhicher, prepared by the Selectmen— That to Hayden was conformable to the rule agreed upon with the Selectmen; but the Deed to Whicher had a clause inserted stipulating that if at the end of the term the parties should not agree to renew the lease, the Grantors—the town, should pay for all fruit- and ornament trees raised on the ground, at an appraisement. No such stipulation had been proposed or mentioned, and we all agreed not to assent to it— Mr Greenleaf said that Mr Marden had made application for a half an Acre of the land on Mount Ararat; and the question was what ground rent should be required and for what term of time, the lease should be given— Both the gentlemen thought that half the price paid for the half-acre on the Hancock lot would be a suitable estimate for a house lot of the same dimensions on Mount Ararat—but I recommended that if that should be assumed as the standard the lease should be only for 50 years;—and that if the lease should be for 99 years the ground-rent reserved should be twenty dollars a year to which they agreed— Mr Greenleaf spoke also of the late Town-meeting to consider the question of celebrating next May the second centennial anniversary of the incorporation of the town of Braintree. A party opposition to it has been gotten up and the vote in favour of it was 28 to 22. A committee of 7 were chosen, Mr T. Greenleaf Chairman, to confer with Committees from the towns of Braintree and Randolph— But the Committee are all whigs. Mr Greenleaf said the Committee were to meet next Tuesday— I said there had been several intimations in the Newspapers and otherwise that the towns might think of charging me with the duty of delivering the centennial discourse— I wished him to inform the Committees that it will not be in my power— They both said they thought the best thing will be to drop it altogether and have no celebration. I said I hoped not— I thought the celebration would be gratifying to the People, and useful for preserving a memorial of a history of the three town. But independent of the fact that the day falls at the very busiest period of the Session of Congress, and when it may be impossible for me to absent myself, if I should deliver the address I should feel it my duty to give a particular account of the history of each of the three and should need the whole winter to look up and search out the documents of all three—a work which it would be utterly impossible for me to perform— And finally I would in no case perform at such a celebration with a party opposition against it— Charles and his wife went to Boston this morning—returned to dine, and were here this Evening— Dr Holbrook is here, and is treating Fanny for a severe bilious fever— Louisa C. Smith also continues quite ill.
26. IV. Saturday

Louisa C. Smith and Fanny both continue very unwell—the child so as to give us great uneasiness. Miss Sampson the seamstress who has been here since Tuesday Morning, left us this Evening and returned home to Braintree— Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Harrod were here this afternoon and came again to tea, and with Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— I have chosen the Smithsonian bequest as my subject for a Lecture to the Quincy Lyceum which I last Wednesday promised Mr John A. Green now its President to deliver deo adjuvante on Wednesday the 20th. of next Month— This subject weighs deeply upon my mind— The private interests and sordid passions into which that fund has already fallen, fill me with anxiety and apprehensions that it will be squandered upon cormorants or wasted in electioneering bribery— The apparent total indifference of Mr Van Buren, to the disposal of the money, with his general professions of a disposition to aid me—the assentation of all the heads of department without a particle of assistance from any one of them, excepting the Attorney General Grundy, whose favourable opinion Cambreleng at the last Session contrived to nullify—the opposition open and disguised of Calhoun, Preston and Waddy Thomson, even to the establishment of the institution in any form, the utter prostration of all public Spirit in the Senate, proved by the encouragement which they gave to the mean and selfish project of Asher Robbins to make a University for him to be placed at the head of it, the investment of the whole fund, more than half a Million of dollars in Arkansas and Michigan State Stocks; and the dirty trick of filching ten thousand dollars from the fund last Winter to pay for the charges of procuring it, are all so utterly discouraging, that I despair of effecting any thing for the honour of the country or even to accomplish the purpose of the bequest the increase and diffusion of knowledge among men— It is hard to toil through life for a great purpose with a conviction that it will be in vain; but possibly seed now sown may bring forth some good fruit hereafter— In my report of January 1836.— I laid down all the general principles upon which the fund should have been accepted and administered. I was then wholly successful— My Bill passed without opposition, and under its provisions the money was procured and deposited in the Treasury in gold— If I cannot present the disgrace of the Country by the failure of the testator’s intention by making it the subject of a Lecture, I can leave a record for future time of what I have done, and what I would have done to accomplish the great design, if executed Well— And let not the supplication to the author of all good, be wanting.
27. IV:15 Sunday.

Heard Mr Cunningham of Dorchester; in the morning from Matthew 22.12. “And he saith unto him, Friend, how camest thou in hither, not having a Wedding garment? and he was speechless.” The discourse began, by a reference to a doctrine of the followers of Emmanuel Swedenborg that the Soul of every individual after death, will range among the spheres till it shall find a place for the special enjoyments for which it is fitted.
