Mr Cunningham remarked that this was a mere conjecture, concerning our condition in a future state, of which we know absolutely nothing— But he said that such was undoubtedly the condition of the Soul in the present world, and that no man could have any other enjoyments than those for which he is fitted, and that without the wedding garment, he cannot partake of the marriage feast— And that as there was no evidence that any moral revolution or change was effected upon the Soul by the mere operation of death, there was good reason for the Swedenborgian opinion, on this point— I believe this doctrine neither peculiar to Swedenborg nor original with him— I have heard it preached long before the name of Swedenborg was known in this Country— But I know not whether the selection of the text was in absolute good taste— The parable alludes to manners and customs familiar to the age and country in which it was delivered but not strictly applicable now— Wedding garments that is dresses more costly than those usually worn are now common, for the parties to the marriage; but they differ from them by no peculiar distinction, nor do the guests of the feast wear them at all. Court dresses are still worn and required in the palaces and presence of kings, but not in this Country, though we have still military uniforms— But even at this day, a king who should send his servants into the high ways, when the wedding was ready, to bid as many as they should find to the feast, and then upon seeing one of them without a Court dress, should call him to account, and order him to be bound hand and foot and cast into outer darkness, would not pass for a good king. Mr Cunningham dined with us—and Charles who was his Classmate at Cambridge. The afternoon Sermon was from Ecclesiastes 3.1. “To every thing there is a Season.” The illustrations of this thought throughout the whole chapter are so numerous and so diversified that it would seem as if nothing could be added to them. But the most earnest part of the discourse was an admonition to the auditory that there is not only a time to be born, but a time to die, a consideration, peculiarly incumbent upon a man at my time of life to ponder— I read a Sermon of Barrow, upon the text thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself—full of thought and closely argumentative—but the style is obsolete and the reasoning is dry and crusty, as if it were the solution of a problem in Algebra— Dr. Holbrook was here and E. Price Greenleaf, Charles and his wife this Evening.
28. IV. Monday.

Mr Albert Smith of North Bridgewater came with a Letter from Eliab Whitman, Chairman of the Town Committee of whigs of that town, stating that for several weeks past their whole community has been disturbed and agitated by the discussion of political subjects, and as the annual State election approaches, the excitement increases and pervades more or less the whole community— That the democratic party having been for several years past in a minority, have of late become exceedingly active in making proselytes, and that they have recently procured a gentleman to lecture on the currency; and that there is to be a second, and a third Lecture— That the whig citizens of North-Bridgewater have recently determined to meet their enemies in their own way, by a lecture touching the general features of the National Administration and also those of this State, and that immediate application should be made to me to perform this Service— He refers me for particulars to Mr Smith, who for the last two years has been a Representative of the Town in the general Court, and urged me very earnestly to comply with this invitation— I said to Mr Smith that I was grateful for the confidence manifested by my fellow-citizens of North-Bridgewater; and regretted that my engagements, and the short time within which it would be necessary for me to proceed to Washington made it impossible for me to comply with their request— I said further that I approved generally of the principles and measures of the Administration of the State; and disapproved of almost every thing done by the federal Administration— But that I had always professed not to be a party man, and wished to preserve that character to the end— That I had sometimes supported important measures of the administration against the general opinions of the whig party; and that even now upon the subject of the license Law, to which they were devoted, I had already given the opinion that it would be desirable it should be modified— I made sundry other observations to shew that some other person would be more suitable for this service than me— He then asked me if I could recommend any person, but I knew of none— He finally said he would go and consult Mr Robert C. Winthrop, and I thought he could do no better— He said that his business would not admit of his going to the General Court next year and Mr Whitman who was an able lawyer would be the whig candidate to go in his place— He took Mr Whitman’s Letter to shew to Mr Winthrop, and said he would send it to me to-morrow— I received also a printed circular from Washington City signed Joseph Butler, with a Prospectus for a Newspaper to be called the Washington whig and solicitation of patronage— My wife and Charles’s went to Boston this afternoon, and returned in the Evening— He went in the morning and returned to dine— I dined with him; and from after dinner till dark visited My seminary and Orchard where I planted a row of Acorns, shagbark walnuts and Peach stones— Almost all my seedling trees in the garden have been uprooted and transplanted—
29. IV:10. Tuesday.

Fine autumnal day. My address on the Smithsonian bequest in preparation for the Quincy Lyceum, as usual grows upon me as I proceed; and I fear I shall not be able to include the subject as I propose to discuss it in one Lecture. My main object must be to prepare for action upon it at the approaching Session of Congress; and to gather facts and arguments for a last effort to save the fund from misapplication dilapidation and waste— Mr James H. Foster, and his wife were here this forenoon, to see her Sister Louisa C Smith, and Dr Holbrook this afternoon, to see her and Fanny, both of whom are afflicted with lingering and distressing diseases— Mr E. Price Greenleaf also came and inspected the Apple seedlings budded by him on the 3d. and 10th. of August last, and found almost all of them in good condition. My seminary border has been thinned of two maple and sundry other trees, and almost all my seedling trees in the garden and Nursery have been plucked up, and transplanted in to the Orchard— Mr Minott Thayer of Braintree, with Dr. Alden of Randolph, and Mr George W. Beale, came as a deputation of the three towns of Braintree Randolph and Quincy, from their joint Committees, and informed me, that at their meeting this day, they had unanimously agreed to commemorate the second centennial anniversary of the incorporation of the Town of Braintree— That the Address should be delivered in the Town of Braintree; and that I should be requested to deliver it. I told them that I was very glad they had agreed that the commemoration should be held, and perfectly satisfied that it should be in Braintree. But I regretted that it would be impossible for me to deliver the Address in as much as the day would be the 25th of May, at the very busiest period of the Session of Congress when upon full consideration I had come to the conclusion that I could not be justified in absenting my self from my duty in the House of Representatives—besides which there was much information respecting the history and Statistics of the three towns, which the speaker for the day should be collecting through the whole succeeding winter, but which would be altogether impossible for me. Doctor Alden then said it would be quite immaterial that the Discourse should be delivered precisely upon the day of the anniversary— If this should happen on a Sunday, it would necessarily be postponed till the next day; and if for one day it might as well be postponed to any reasonable time— He asked if I would undertake to deliver the discourse on some day after the close of the Session next Summer or fall, I said I would, and they are to report this to the committee, of the three towns— Mr Thayer remained and took tea here, after the other Gentlemen went away— He presented me a vote of thanks from the inhabitants of Braintree in Town Meeting on the 25th. of October, for my discourse of the preceding day, and a request of a copy of it for publication; and a vote that it be printed— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
30. IV: Wednesday
Sun rose 6:31. Set 4:59.

President Quincy called upon me this morning, with a subscription paper to raise two thousand dollars for the erection of an Astronomical observatory at Cambridge, to be connected with Harvard University. He said he had made it a point of honour to offer this paper first to me, and I subscribed for one hundred dollars— The condition of the subscription was that the amount subscribed should be at least two thousand dollars— He said he had no doubt of raising the money, and should subscribe one hundred dollars himself— That they had already fixed upon the spot for the building, and that Mr Bond was engaged upon the work— This has been many years an object of earnest desire to me, and of long regret that I had not the means of founding such an establishment myself— I once offered 1000 dollars towards it; but the design was of a larger establishment, and the subscription could not be filled— Mr Pearce Cranch, and Mrs Mary Dawes were here this afternoon and Miss Torrey who keeps the school where our children usually attend; though the sickness of Fanny still very severe has now confined her a full week to her bed—and her Sister Mary-Louisa was sent up the hill this evening, to sleep at Charles’s house— Mrs Stebbins, with Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary W. Harrod were then here a short time, and went to take tea at Mr Beale’s— Soon after Mrs T. B. Adams came in and called out Charles’s wife. She had been in to Boston this morning alone, and consulted Dr Warren, about a complaint under which she has been some time suffering, but concealed— He informed her that it was a schirrous cancer and that it must be immediately removed. She came back and determined to have the operation performed the day after to-morrow. But she wishes it may not be made known, to her daughter Elizabeth, or to Mary W. Harrod who is now here with her— And she wishes equally to conceal it from her daughter Mrs John Angier at Medford— Her purpose is therefore to induce Elizabeth and Miss Harrod to go the day after to-morrow on a visit to Mrs Angier at Medford, and to send a note to-morrow to Dr Warren, to come the next Morning at ten O’Clock to perform the operation— Mrs Charles Adams is to write the note, and I am to take it to Boston to-morrow.— My wife and Mrs Charles are to go to the House to be there when Dr Warren is to use the knife, but Mrs Stebbins only is to be with her Sister— This is a sudden and a severe trial— I am now kept almost constantly in the house and cannot even visit my Garden, Nursery Seminary and Orchard— As I approach the close of the paper I had laid out for my lecture upon the Smithsonian beques, I find that one Lecture will not contain all that I wish to say upon the subject— I must overflow into a second—
31. IV. Thursday.
Boston— Historical Society, Meeting— Quincy

I went into Boston this Morning, in Charles’s Chaise with one of my own horses and Thomas to drive me— I went immediately to the chamber of the City Council in the old Town-house and examined the fair copy of the most antient town records— I wished to find the entries respecting Mount Wollaston and Braintree; but they were so numerous that I could only copy three or four, and could even read only a few pages, and noon came, and I was obliged to repair to the Meeting of the Historical Society.— The President Thomas L Winthrop was in the Chair—I returned Fairfield’s journal, and the Manuscript Sermons of Mr Wheelwright and of Moses Fiske which I had borrowed at the last Meeting for Mr Lunt— And I proposed his name as a resident member of the Society, in the place of Dr Gamaliel Bradford who died suddenly since the last meeting.— The answer to Mr Daniel D. Barnard to his election as an honorary member of the Society was read, and with it he sent nine of his discourses and addresses to literary Societies— Dr Thaddeus Mason Harris my Classmate after reading a report of his late proceedings as Secretary of the Society resigne that office stating that he was going to the South to be absent several Months— He told me he was writing a life of General Oglethorpe for publication and was going to Georgia to collect materials. And he asked me for a Letter of recommendation— Mr Berrien the President, and Mr Tefft the Secretary of the new Georgia Historical Society were balloted for and elected as honorary members of the Society, and Robert C. Winthrop as a residing member— Mr Nahum Mitchell the Treasurer of the Society gave notice that he had not money to pay the book binders bill for books bound by direction of the Secretary. Mr Nathan Appleton after some discussion, engaged to advance the money to pay the Bill. President Quincy was there and shewed me the list of subscribers which he had obtained since yesterday Morning—sixteen, for one hundred dollars each, for the astronomical observatory at Cambridge, among the names I observed with peculiar pleasure that of Mr P. C. Brooks— I spoke to Mr Lemuel Shattuck about the Letter and Documents I have received from him respecting the Adams family, and promised to send him the genealogical table of Elijah Adams— I accepted the invitation of Mr Winthrop to dine with him— After the adjournment of the meeting I visited Miss Cutts at Mr B. W. Crowninshield’s and saw her with Miss Elizabeth Crowninshield. I called afterwards at Dr George Parkman’s. Dined at Mr Winthrop’s, with N. Appleton James T. Austin, Dr John Codman Judge Davis and I. P. Davis. Mr Felt, Dr T. M. Harris, Dr John Pierce President Quincy, Mr Savage, Miss Tappan, Joseph Willard, Miss Winthrop, Robert C. Winthrop, and Dr Alexander Young— I got home soon after 6. Mr and Mrs W. Appleton and Charles and his wife here this Evening.
